etymologies: mid 17th century: from Latin convuls- ‘pulled violently, wrenched’, from the verb convellere, from con- ‘together’ + vellere ‘to pull’

definitions: (of a person) suffer violent involuntary contraction of the muscles, producing contortion of the body or limbs

examples.text: she convulsed, collapsing to the floor with the pain

shortDefinitions: suffer violent involuntary contraction of muscles

definitions: (of an emotion, laughter, or physical stimulus) cause (someone) to make sudden, violent, uncontrollable movements

examples.text: she rocked backward and forward, convulsed with helpless mirth
Carlos was convulsed by a second bout of sneezing

shortDefinitions: cause someone to make sudden, violent, uncontrollable movements

definitions: throw (a country) into violent social or political upheaval

examples.text: a wave of mass strikes convulsed the Ruhr, Berlin, and central Germany

shortDefinitions: throw country into violent social or political upheaval
